clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Self-Collected Saliva Samples Without Viral Transport Media for SARS-CoV-2 Testing Via RT-PCR
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Self-Collected Saliva Samples Without Viral Transport Media for SARS-CoV-2 Testing Via RT-PCR

lead_sponsor.agency: David Grant U.S. Air Force Medical Center

clinical_study.source: David Grant U.S. Air Force Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: This is a study that will attempt to validate the process for detecting SARS-CoV-2 (COVID19) using self-collected saliva as the specimen. We will compare self-collected saliva samples and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples (Nasal swabs) to see if the self-collected saliva samples are similar in terms of diagnostic accuracy. We will be performing this testing at the site where patients regularly go for COVID19 testing. There will be minimal risk of harm as consenting patients will only have to provide a small amount of saliva into a tube.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a descriptive study that will attempt to validate the procedure for detecting SARS-CoV-2 on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system using self-collected saliva as the specimen. We will calculate the percent agreement and the 95% confidence intervals (ie, overall agreement, percent positive agreement, and percent negative agreement) between self-collected saliva samples (evaluated on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system) and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples (evaluated on either the BioFire® FilmArray® Torch® system or the Cepheid® GeneXpert® as the gold standard). Participants without usable results for both the saliva and nasopharyngeal methods will not be included in the analyses. Currently, DGMC uses both FDA Emergency Use Authorization systems interchangeably to test for SARS-CoV-2.
Using human volunteers to obtain positive and negative nasopharyngeal and saliva specimens of SARS-COV-2, this is a test validation study. It uses the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system to compare the test performance of saliva as a specimen to the standard nasopharyngeal specimen.
This protocol utilizes a convenience sample of patients presenting to the DGMC COVID screening tent. Therefore, the study population will be comprised of active duty, DoD dependents, retirees, DoD civilian, and contract personnel presenting to the COVID screening test under their own accord for testing out of concern for exposure to, or symptoms related to, COVID. This study will enroll up to 600 individuals. From that group, the results of approximately 30 COVID-19 positive (by NP test) participants and a sequentially selected sample of approximately 30 COVID-19 negative (by NP test) participants will be utilized to compare NP swab to saliva sample results. The remaining samples collected will be stored for future testing if authorized.
Recruitment and enrollment efforts for this study will be conducted at the DGMC COVID Screening Tent as patients present for COVID-19 testing. COVID Tent personnel will provide an informational flyer to all patients. Those interested in enrolling will be given an informed consent and HIPAA Authorization form by COVID tent personnel to read, then instructed to contact the study team using a cell phone. Study personnel will discuss the study, review both documents with the patient, and answer questions to their satisfaction over the phone. To minimize contact with potentially infected patients, study team members will not enter the COVID tent. A study team member will meet outdoors nearby the COVID tent with the prospective study participant to sign original versions of both documents to allow access to the medical record in order to retrieve NP COVID-19 test results, and obtain the saliva sample. The study team member will wear a lab coat, gloves, and mask. To minimize contact with potentially infected participants, study team members will not enter the COVID tent but will primarily discuss the study details, informed consent and HIPAA authorization by phone. The COVID tent staff will provide patients who are interested in participating in the study with a flyer stating the study team contact information and will provide interested patients with a copy of the study informed consent document and HIPAA Authorization form. Interested participants will be directed by the COVID tent staff to immediately call the study team. The participant will keep the copy of the informed consent document provided by the COVID tent staff. At the conclusion of the phone conversation regarding study details, a study team member will meet outdoors with the prospective study participant. The study team member will wear a lab coat, gloves, and mask. Specifically, the participants will be consented to allow their medical record to be accessed in order to view their NP COVID-19 test results. At the same time Demographic information (age, ethnicity, race and gender) will be captured and study staff will ensure the participant has not smoked, eaten or drank anything for the previous 10 minutes. Then participants will be given a biohazard bag with a label (with a 6-numerical code) and 25 ml plastic specimen tube without transport medium inside, then asked to fill it with approximately 2mL of saliva. There will be a marking on the tube to ensure a sufficient sample is collected. The participant will be instructed to close the lid, place the label on the outside of the tube, then put the tube into the biohazard bag. The participant will then place the bagged specimen inside a second biohazard bag held by the study team member. The study team member will place the double-bagged saliva sample into the study cooler with ice. The study team member will record the code on the consent and HIPAA authorization forms. All items will then be transported to the CIF.
This study will utilize the result of the standard of care NP COVID-19 test performed in the COVID tent for comparison to the saliva sample obtained for research. Approximately 30 positive and 30 negative NP results from participants will be tested for COVID-19, since the FDA advises this number for validation of new COVID-19 testing methodologies. The saliva testing results and NP testing results will then be compared.
The study goal is to obtain saliva samples from participants representing 30 positive and 30 negative NP COVID-19 samples, however, the participants will not be evenly distributed. More negative than positive participants will be recruited. We will seek approval to enroll 600 participants. The results are expected to be 94% COVID-19 negative and 6% COVID-19 positive based on the prevalence for Solano County in August 2020. It is therefore anticipated that approximately 500 participants would need to be enrolled to obtain 30 positive results. To balance the many negative test results from participants, the samples will be collected from every participant, but only saliva samples from every 10th participant with a negative result will be utilized in the study. Once 30 positive results and 30 negative results are recruited, the study will be closed to recruitment.
Testing will be performed on saliva samples using reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RTPCR). Natural and/or synthetic RNA will be acquired for use as a positive control. RT-PCR will target the N-gene of SARS-CoV-2.
1. Within 5 minutes of sample collection the sample will be put on ice for stabilization. A cooler with ice will be taken to the outdoor location where the participant provides the sample. The sample will be put in a biohazard bag, then immediately be placed into the cooler for transport to the CIF Microbiology Laboratory.
2. Ribonucleic Acid (RNA) Extraction - Within 12 hours, RNA will be extracted from the specimens using Invitrogen PureLink ® Viral RNA/DNA Mini Kit (Life Technologies). 3. Sample RNA will be stored at -80oC until used.
3. SuperScriptTM III One-Step RT-PCR with PlatinumTM Taq (Life Technologies) will be used for detection and amplification of viral RNA present in specimens using Eppendorf Mastercyler Pro S (Eppendorf). Seven primer pairs that are based from CDC and other publications will be used 18-19. Three from the envelope protein gene and four from the nucleocapsid protein gene.
4. Frozen samples will be tested and run in batches.
5. PCR products will be evaluated with gel electrophoresis using the Mini-Protein® Tetra Cell (Bio-Rad).
6. Sequencing - All PCR reactions that produce acceptable amplicons will be stored at -80oC for possible sequencing confirmation using the ABI 3130 (Life Technologies).
Once testing is completed, specimens will be aliquoted and stored at -80C. All specimens in the not to be ran cohort will also be aliquoted and stored at -80C.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent positive agreement between self-collected saliva samples and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples
primary_outcome.description: Percent positive agreement between self-collected saliva samples (evaluated on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system) and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples (evaluated on either the BioFire® FilmArray® Torch® system or the Cepheid® GeneXpert® as the gold standard).

primary_outcome.measure: Percent negative agreement between self-collected saliva samples and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples
primary_outcome.description: Percent negative agreement between self-collected saliva samples (evaluated on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system) and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples (evaluated on either the BioFire® FilmArray® Torch® system or the Cepheid® GeneXpert® as the gold standard).

primary_outcome.measure: Percent overall agreement between self-collected saliva samples and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples
primary_outcome.description: Percent overall agreement between self-collected saliva samples (evaluated on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system) and healthcare-worker collected nasopharyngeal samples (evaluated on either the BioFire® FilmArray® Torch® system or the Cepheid® GeneXpert® as the gold standard).

arm_group.description: SARS-CoV-2 testing on self-collected saliva specimens, associated with a positive NP result, using the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) system
SARS-CoV-2 testing on self-collected saliva specimens, associated with a 10th negative NP result, using the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) system

intervention.intervention_name: SARS-CoV-2 testing on the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler PCR system using self-collected saliva as the specimen
intervention.description: Obtain self-collected saliva sample, perform SARS-CoV-2 testing using the Eppendorf Thermal Cycler Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) system on every sample associated with a positive or 10th negative NP sample, then compare saliva results to healthcare worker collected NP sample results evaluated on either the BioFire® FilmArray® Torch® system or the Cepheid® GeneXpert® (gold standard).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients who present to the DGMC COVID tent to receive ambulatory SARS-COV-2 testing
- Willing to provide a saliva sample on the same day, during study availability hours
- Access to a cellular phone so they are able to contact the study team after their COVID tent nasopharyngeal SARS-COV-2 test is collected.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients unwilling to wait or have eaten, drank or smoked within the past 10 minutes
- Patients unwilling or unable to provide 2 mls of saliva
- Patients who are not DoD beneficiaries who are unwilling to provide department of defense identification number for billing purposes.

J Clin Microbiol. 2020 Jul 23;58(8). pii: e01109-20. doi: 10.1128/JCM.01109-20. Print 2020 Jul 23.
